Award.AwardTitle: P2C2: P-E Land-C: Terrestrial Mediation of Carbon Cycle Response Through the Paleocene-Eocene Thermal Maximum
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award to the University of Utah will support field, laboratory, and modeling studies to constrain the role of terrestrial biogeochemical change in modulating the environmental and climatic evolution of the Paleocene-Eocene thermal maximum (PETM). The PETM is a well-documented geological episode of carbon-cycle induced global change that had major repercussions on Earth's environmental and biotic systems. Although a general understanding of the causes and nature of PETM change has been established, a number of anomalous characteristics of the event, including its long duration, high apparent climate sensitivity, and rapid termination, remain unexplained. This project will determine whether changes in the terrestrial critical zone, including carbon storage in land plants and soils, formation of inorganic soil carbonate, and burial of organic and inorganic carbon in continental sedimentary rocks, occurred during the PETM and contributed to the pattern of global change observed during the event. Field studies and lab analyses will document critical zone carbon storage changes at sites in the western USA and Spain and reconstruct local environmental conditions that accompanied these changes. New computer model components will be developed and applied to evaluate the degree to which the observed changes were globally significant and the patterns of global climatic and carbon cycle change that they would have induced, thus providing a more comprehensive understanding of the PETM event. This new information will be incorporated in educational materials, targeted at the graduate, undergraduate, and high-school levels, that communicate the role of the carbon cycle coupled Earth system change over geological and human timescales.

Continental ecosystems store a vast amount of carbon, which is potentially easily transferred to or taken up from the atmosphere, affecting global climate. The response of these systems to global change represents a major source of uncertainty in projections of future environmental conditions, as well as a fundamental unknown in our understanding of the geological record of past climate. This work will test ideas about how carbon storage changes as global climate warms, developed based on the study of modern ecosystems, through a focused study of one of the best-documented episodes of rapid climatic warming in the geologic record. The results will improve our understanding of the role of terrestrial carbon cycle feedback as a mediator of global change, advancing our ability to interpret the paleoclimate record and project future changes in Earth's climate.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Changing atmospheric carbon dioxide concentrations have been associated with major changes in climate at various times during Earth’s geologic history. Although no geologic climate change event is a perfect guide to current and future climate conditions, by studying these ancient events we can learn about the fundamental processes that can govern climate and its response to changing CO2 levels. This project developed new techniques and new records to document past terrestrial climate conditions and processes associated with periods of high atmospheric CO2 levels between 65 and 50 million years ago.

The Intellectual Merit contributions of the project can be grouped into three categories. First, our work developed new mathematical approaches and tools to improve the reconstruction of past climatic and environmental conditions. Because researchers cannot directly measure values such as atmospheric temperature or CO2 levels at times in the distant past, reconstructions of such values are based on “proxy” evidence: physical, chemical, or biological properties of these past environments that can be measured and are indirectly related to the variables of interest. Accurately interpreting these indirect data, and the uncertainty of reconstructions stemming from them, however, is challenging, particularly when researchers wish to combine multiple different proxy measurements to better constrain their interpretations. Our project proposed a statistical approach to this problem which addresses this challenge using mathematical models that represent how the proxy signal is formed and recorded in the geological record. We developed and published software that allows researchers to apply this method and a new proxy model for one commonly-used type of proxy. Our work demonstrated the value of this approach and provided a set of tools that should advance reconstruction of past climatic and environmental conditions.

Second, we produced new proxy data that documents subtropical, continental climate conditions in North America between ~65 and 53 million years ago. This period of time was characterized by higher-than-modern atmospheric CO2 levels and warmer-than-modern global climate. Although excellent records of climate and environment exist from mid-latitude sites in the USA, little information was previously available from low latitudes. Our new records from western Texas show relatively humid, warm conditions, with a substantial increase in temperature coupled with rising CO2 levels through the study period. Although the reconstructed temperatures are warmer than those at these same sites today, comparison with records from Wyoming suggest that the gradient in temperature between low- and mid-latitude sites was lower than today. This supports the idea that as global climate warms, warming in the continental interiors is greater than at coastal sites.

Third, our work investigated a process that is of concern as a potential positive feedback on future climate change: the release of carbon from soils as climate warms. Under higher temperature conditions during periods of global warmth, microbial processes in soils are expected to accelerate, potentially speeding the decay of organic material stored within soils. In many locations, this may be amplified by lower-rainfall and/or higher-evaporation conditions, which can both speed decay of organic matter and reduce the growth of vegetation (and input of organic matter into soils). We examined soils formed during a geologically brief period of extreme climate warming ~56 million years ago, and found that across 3 mid-latitude sites the amount of organic matter stored in these soils during the peak of global warmth was only ~1/2 of that stored before or after the event. Although the number of study sites available is not enough to determine whether this pattern is uniform, globally, our finding support some models for future change which suggest that carbon release from many types of soils may amplify the impact of ongoing increases in atmospheric CO2 levels and temperature.

The Broader Impacts of this project include advances to understanding of climate and biogeochemical changes associated with high atmospheric CO2 levels, development and improvement of teaching materials related to the carbon cycle, and training of a diverse group of Earth science researchers and educators. The Intellectual Merit results described above relate to scientific understanding of climate change, one of the most pressing environmental challenges facing society today. Findings related to spatial climate impacts and carbon cycle feedbacks contribute to a body of knowledge that will be critical to informed policy-making in response to ongoing anthropogenic modification of the carbon cycle. The PI has developed a semester-length, graduate-level course on the carbon cycle, integrating geological, biological, and social science perspectives. As part of this project the geological content and laboratories were updated and improved to better reflect current understanding of soil carbon feedbacks. All course materials were made publically available and have been adopted by other instructors, including in a new course at the University of Ottawa. One PhD student, two undergraduates, and one secondary school teacher were engaged in and trained as part of the research; two of the four were women.
